title: WCAS GERMAN 242-0-20 Imagining Modern Jewish Culture in Yiddish and German
topic: Imagining Modern Jewish Culture in Yiddish

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
No prior knowledge of Jewish culture or history is required for this class (though if students have such that is great!) and the course is of equal interest to Jews and non-Jews.

The first three decades of the twentieth century witnessed an unprecedented renaissance in secular modern Jewish culture. One of the hallmarks of this renaissance was the dynamic artistic and intellectual interaction between young German and German-speaking Jews with their counterparts in Eastern Europe. Kafka discovered the Hasidic tales of Nahman of Bratslav. Martin Buber drew the world's attention to the vibrant mystical culture of Eastern European Jews. Golems (man-made men) Dibbuks (demonic possessors) began to appear in the leading theatres of Europe. Marc Chagall stormed the art worlds of Berlin and Paris with his bizarre avant-garde representations of Eastern European Jewish life on canvas. Gustav Mahler incorporated Jewish folksong into his symphonies.

We examine all of these figures and others in this course. Thus students will be introduced both to key Jewish writers in German?Franz Kafka, Gershom Scholem, Walter Benjamin and others?and the leading writers of modern Yiddish literature?Mendele the Bookseller, Sholem Aleichem, Y.L. Peretz and others.

Guest speakers, all leading scholars in their fields at this university, may provide us with presentations.

Great emphasis is placed on student participation in all class discussions. Two students will be assigned to provide an informal class presentation together for one session a quarter.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This class should expand the students` intellectual horizons. The course serves as an ideal introduction to the history and culture of the Jews in the modern world. The course provides an opening to the magnificent, yet little-known, world of modern Yiddish literature. In addition, this is an apprenticeship in critical thought in the widest sense of the term?as applied not only to literary texts but also to paintings, film, music.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Great emphasis is placed on student participation in all class discussions.

Two three-page essays will be assigned in the course of the term and one final paper of 7-10 pages.

Paper, final: 7-10 page final paper 40% of final grade
Papers: Two three-page papers per quarter 15% each toward final grade
Presentations: 20% of final grade

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The following books are available at Beck's books: Franz Kafka, Amerika; Sholem Aleichem, Tevye the Dairyman; and S. Ansky, The Dybbuk. The other texts for the course will be available at Quartet Copies and/or on Blackboard.
